text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Darrell Lane and Bill Vernon. Clifford Simak is a veteran science fiction writer who has been producing short stories and novels continuously since 1938. Simak won the International Fantasy Award for his City Series, Hugo Awards for his stories at the Big Front Yard, and The Grotto of the Dancing Deer, and the novel Way Station. And he was honored by his peers when they presented him with the Grandmaster Nebula Award. Simak's prolific output is remarkable when one learns that until his retirement a few years ago, he was a full-time newspaper man. We asked him how he decided to become a newspaper man. There was no decision because I think I always knew what I wanted to write. And I never really thought of writing fiction or writing books or anything of that sort. It seemed to me that the way to write was to be a newspaper man. My mother, who was a very well-educated woman, had books in the house all the time, and I read them. Despite the fact that we were poor, we got a daily paper. And she used to sit at the table by the light of a kerosene lamp and read it each evening after all the work was done. And I asked her at one time, I remember, if a newspaper carried all the news, printed all the news there was. And she, in the manner of that day, and because people were not as cynical then as they are now, said, yes, that was true. And I asked her another question that I thought was important. I said, is all the news true? Is what the newspaper writes true? And again, with that lack of cynicism and faith that the people of that time had, she said, yes, it was. And that decided me, decided me to want to be a newspaper man. So Simak did become a newspaper man, but eventually he found that the type of writing it required did not completely satisfy him. We asked him why he chose science fiction when he decided to write fiction. Well, because when I was a boy, I had read Joe's Word and I think H.G. Wells, although I don't actually remember any H.G. Wells works, but I must have read them. Edgar Allan Poe and Haggard. And I thought what a wonderful thing that was. I just had an awful interest in the field. I wanted to read it myself, and I found out when I decided that I wanted to write, when I found out that newspaper didn't give me everything that I wanted in the writing field, I decided that on my spare time I write, I naturally seemed to turn to science fiction, because it was something I was acquainted with. I felt very sure that I could do the job of it. And I was quite fortunate, of course, because there was no competition at that time. If you could string in three sentences together and make a paragraph, somebody would buy the story. CIMEC's combination of professions is, on the surface, a strange mixture. After all, newspaper writing requires a lean, straightforward type of prose, whereas fiction requires much fuller writing. We asked CIMEC if he thought the styles required are significantly different. They are absolutely upwards. But I compartmentalized my life into two lives. When I went to work in the morning, I was a newspaper man. And when I came home and sat down at my desk at night, I was a fiction writer. More on Clifford CIMEC in our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. It's in Valentine's 2 Chronicles Krieg, 2012 establishments, and S Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Science fiction writer Clifford Simak has been publishing almost continuously every year since 1938. Right, but Simak's first stories were published several years earlier. Here he explains how his writing career got started and how it was temporarily stopped. I started my newspaper career in 1929, and my first short story appeared in, I think, 1931. And I wrote, at that time, I wrote several other short stories which were published. And at about that time, the magazine, all magazines, the science fiction magazines and all others, ran into hard times because the Great Depression came along. And so there was no market, practically no market. So I dropped out and didn't do any more writing, any other fiction writing of any kind, until I think it was 37 or 38. And I started writing again because the magazines had come back. John Camel had been named editor of Astounding. And I felt fairly sure I could sell my work to John Camel. So I started writing again. And I think since 1938 and 1939, I think it's 38, 37 or 38, there was only one year in which none of my work appeared. There was one year that's blank. And I can't remember which year that it was, and I have no idea why that occurred. So Simak became an early mainstay in John W. Campbell's Stable of Writers at Astounding Stories. We asked Simak why he thought his work appealed to Campbell. I'd read a lot of John Campbell's work. And I knew it. I knew it. John Campbell was favored what we today call hard science fiction. And I thought that I could write that kind of science fiction. I did write what amounted to hard science fiction for some years, and then begin to turn over to the softer science fiction, such most of which, well, most people write soft science fiction today. Only a few of the old hands and maybe a few new beginners write the hard science fiction today. During the first few decades he wrote, Simak produced short stories almost exclusively. We asked him to tell us why he stuck to the short story form. Short stories is the trading ground for the novelist. Short stories is the trading ground for the novelist. You can learn a lot more from writing a short story than you can writing a novel. It's shorter to write, somewhat easier to write. You don't have the time invested in a short story to do a novel. If you spend, as a beginner, probably a six-month-old year writing a novel, and it fails, well, that's catastrophic. But during that same time, you could write a half a dozen short stories, and if only one of them sold, well, okay, you have made a beginning. So it's the path that most people take to becoming writers or long-going work. And that doesn't apply only to the science fiction field, but to any literature. More on Clifford Simak on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. Science fiction author Clifford Simak has written numerous short stories and novels, and he has won several awards in the field. Perhaps Simak's most famous and enduring work is his City Collection, a series of eight interconnected stories written in the 1940s. These stories featured mankind's reaction to a new situation, and man's relationship with an old friend, the dog, and a new one, the robot. Simak agreed when we call these stories a leap from his previous efforts. It was a leap. I was a leap. Because I always regard the city stories as a sort of watershed in my writing. I have been writing the old type of early type science fiction work up until then. And it seemed to me that there was something better could be done than was being done. Strangely enough, at about the same time, a number of other people seemed to think the same thing. There's no accounting for something like that happening. We asked Simak what influenced him to write these revolutionary stories. I think it was my disillusion brought up by the war that made me write the City series. It seemed to me that we were going through a horrible period in history, and that much of human dignity had been sheared away, that it was not the kind of world that we had lived in up until that time. And I found myself wanting to retreat from it. So I retreated from it mentally by going into another dimension, into another world, creating a sort of fantasy where myself and, as it turned out, others also were able to find some refuge. I think if the City series were written today, that they probably would not get the attention that they got back in the early 40s. I wrote them exactly the right kind of story at exactly the right time, without knowing I was doing it. John Campbell published the first seven city stories, but he rejected the eighth. Here Simak tells us of its fate. The first seven were written fairly well, one after the other. The eighth and final one, John Campbell turned down, because he said he thought that he'd written it, that he'd published enough of the City series. And so when he rejected it, I simply threw it up on the shelf, and figured it was one of my rejects. And then the writer took it down, and I think I sold it to Amazing Stories. And I don't recall what they called it, but they put it out with one of their horrible titles. And then later on, when it came out, it joined the others. The last one was not published by Campbell. On our next show, we'll talk about a ninth city story. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show, Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Science Fiction writer Clifford Simak's most famous work is his story collection, City. This collection of eight connected short stories was first published as a body by Nome in 1952. Years afterward, Simak was persuaded to write a ninth city story, Epilogue. Here he explains its genesis. Well, John Camel died. And, of course, all of us, all of us were stricken by his death, because he was a comparable young man and appeared to be in good physical condition. Some of the writers reverence. Some of the writers reverenced him. I'm not too sure I reverenced him, but I felt very kindly to him. It was very badly hit by his death. And a group of writers got together and said we'd have to put out a memorial to John Campbell. And the best way to do it would be to put out the last issue of the old Astoning story. Not analog, but the old Astoning stories. And so they asked, well, I suppose there were a dozen or so people who had written for the old Astoning stories to write a story for the Memorial Mall. And Harry Harrison, who was the editor, phoned me and he said, Cliff, if you will write a story, I wish you'd write another city story. And I was reluctant to do that. I shied away from it because it had been quite a number of years since I'd written the city story. And I knew that I was a changed writer. I was not the same man as I was when I'd written the stories. I worried a great deal about the propriety of writing another city story because I figured that the last one, the last of the day, had wound up the story of the Webster family and that there was no need of going further. But the more I thought about it, the more I began to see that if I was going to write something for that memorial volume, it should be a city story. So for the first time since I'd written them, I took down my copy of the book City and reread it, trying to catch the flavor and the spirit of the stories. And when I read the stories, I simply absolutely ached to rewrite them again because there are some awful crudities in them. But I knew even as I thought about that, that I couldn't do it because if I rewrote them, they wouldn't be the city series. So I sat down and did my best to try to recreate the flavor of the other eight stories. I think I came very close to it, but not as satisfactorily as I might have wanted to. Ace published the nine stories as a group for the first time in 1981. The robots in City are gentle, respectful entities. We asked Simak why he made them so. Most of the writers who had written robots before wrote of them as machines. And I wrote of them as surrogate human beings. I made them people with some of the biases and practices that the living human would have stripped away from them. And I tried to make them the kind of people that I would want to live with. More on Clifford Simak on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Soft philosopher called little text, cause of you on a complex Masonic reporter's voice once it gets on to the medicine. And the cops and computers are moresome. And this has been a challenging time for 105 years. They don't want to live with. The most important thing is maintain the truth for the population, about the poverty level. Hopefully they're stories caatchets, will make him more serious research and sowlexer którą a study, or tentar commencé with mood trees. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane and Bill Vernon. Science fiction author Clifford Simak has been writing for more than 50 years. All his work, especially the well-known pieces such as City, A Choice of Gods, and Waystation, is characterized by a warm sentimental flavor that never cloys. Simak's Midwestern roots and values are evident in his work, and the reader is caught by their charm. We asked Simak if he purposely worked his philosophy into his works. A man's philosophy is so much a part of him that he probably doesn't stop and think about it very often. He doesn't say, well, this is, I'm writing this way because this is the way I think, or this is the way I feel. When you sit down and write, you're writing the way you think and you feel unconsciously, without, without, uh, trying to work at it. Not all of Simak's characters are model citizens, but none are ever terribly evil. We ask Simak why evil plays so small a role in his work. I think I've never been aware of evil. I have been aware of friendship and love and, um, good fellowship and honesty, truth. I, um, I, um, get very concerned at times about the condition of the world, not only now, but in times past. And I know that there is evil. But, uh, but it's, I, I kept it at times, like, not consciously, but, uh, simply because I didn't want, I guess I didn't want to think about it. I, um, I concentrated on, as I said before, on the things that seemed important to me. Did Simak ever dream, back in his early writing days, that science fiction would become a fixture in commercial literature? No, not at all. Never for a moment. We were working in the ghetto. Um, there were very few of us. Uh, science fiction was read by only a handful. When you met somebody and they found out you were a science fiction writer, they'd say, how'd you get those crazy ideas? I, uh, went thinking around, hoping nobody would notice you. Um, you, you were, you were the bottom of the heap. There's no question about it. You were much more despicable than maybe the pornographic writers of today. Um, but we kept at it because we liked it. Because I think, I, I think it, after a few years of it, I began to feel that probably it would develop and it might have a future. But I never dreamed that we would be putting out as great, as great and good a progress as we have. How does Simak want to be remembered as a writer? I don't know if I will be remembered. But if I am to be remembered as a writer, I'd like to be remembered as someone who wrote honestly and who is more concerned with the heart and mind of humanity than with humanity's achievements. Clifford Simak, a writer whose gentle stories have charmed readers for over 50 years. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show,

segments.text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Darrell Lane and Bill Vernon.
Clifford Simak is a veteran science fiction writer who has been producing short stories and novels continuously since 1938.
Simak won the International Fantasy Award for his City Series, Hugo Awards for his stories at the Big Front Yard,
and The Grotto of the Dancing Deer, and the novel Way Station.
And he was honored by his peers when they presented him with the Grandmaster Nebula Award.
Simak's prolific output is remarkable when one learns that until his retirement a few years ago, he was a full-time newspaper man.
We asked him how he decided to become a newspaper man.
There was no decision because I think I always knew what I wanted to write.
And I never really thought of writing fiction or writing books or anything of that sort.
It seemed to me that the way to write was to be a newspaper man.
My mother, who was a very well-educated woman, had books in the house all the time, and I read them.
Despite the fact that we were poor, we got a daily paper.
And she used to sit at the table by the light of a kerosene lamp and read it each evening after all the work was done.
And I asked her at one time, I remember, if a newspaper carried all the news, printed all the news there was.
And she, in the manner of that day, and because people were not as cynical then as they are now, said, yes, that was true.
And I asked her another question that I thought was important.
I said, is all the news true?
Is what the newspaper writes true?
And again, with that lack of cynicism and faith that the people of that time had, she said, yes, it was.
And that decided me, decided me to want to be a newspaper man.
So Simak did become a newspaper man, but eventually he found that the type of writing it required did not completely satisfy him.
We asked him why he chose science fiction when he decided to write fiction.
Well, because when I was a boy, I had read Joe's Word and I think H.G. Wells, although I don't actually remember any H.G. Wells works, but I must have read them.
Edgar Allan Poe and Haggard.
And I thought what a wonderful thing that was.
I just had an awful interest in the field.
I wanted to read it myself, and I found out when I decided that I wanted to write, when I found out that newspaper didn't give me everything that I wanted in the writing field,
I decided that on my spare time I write, I naturally seemed to turn to science fiction,
because it was something I was acquainted with.
I felt very sure that I could do the job of it.
And I was quite fortunate, of course, because there was no competition at that time.
If you could string in three sentences together and make a paragraph, somebody would buy the story.
CIMEC's combination of professions is, on the surface, a strange mixture.
After all, newspaper writing requires a lean, straightforward type of prose, whereas fiction requires much fuller writing.
We asked CIMEC if he thought the styles required are significantly different.
They are absolutely upwards.
But I compartmentalized my life into two lives.
When I went to work in the morning, I was a newspaper man.
And when I came home and sat down at my desk at night, I was a fiction writer.
More on Clifford CIMEC in our next show.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,
produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.

Science fiction writer Clifford Simak has been publishing almost continuously every year since 1938.
Right, but Simak's first stories were published several years earlier.

I started my newspaper career in 1929, and my first short story appeared in, I think, 1931.
And I wrote, at that time, I wrote several other short stories which were published.
And at about that time, the magazine, all magazines, the science fiction magazines and all others,
ran into hard times because the Great Depression came along.
And so there was no market, practically no market.
So I dropped out and didn't do any more writing, any other fiction writing of any kind,
until I think it was 37 or 38.
And I started writing again because the magazines had come back.
John Camel had been named editor of Astounding.
And I felt fairly sure I could sell my work to John Camel.
So I started writing again.
And I think since 1938 and 1939, I think it's 38, 37 or 38, there was only one year in which none of my work appeared.
There was one year that's blank.
And I can't remember which year that it was, and I have no idea why that occurred.
So Simak became an early mainstay in John W. Campbell's Stable of Writers at Astounding Stories.

I'd read a lot of John Campbell's work.

I knew it.

And I thought that I could write that kind of science fiction.
I did write what amounted to hard science fiction for some years,
and then begin to turn over to the softer science fiction, such most of which, well, most people write soft science fiction today.
Only a few of the old hands and maybe a few new beginners write the hard science fiction today.
During the first few decades he wrote, Simak produced short stories almost exclusively.
We asked him to tell us why he stuck to the short story form.
Short stories is the trading ground for the novelist.
Short stories is the trading ground for the novelist.
You can learn a lot more from writing a short story than you can writing a novel.
It's shorter to write, somewhat easier to write.
You don't have the time invested in a short story to do a novel.
If you spend, as a beginner, probably a six-month-old year writing a novel, and it fails, well, that's catastrophic.
But during that same time, you could write a half a dozen short stories,
and if only one of them sold, well, okay, you have made a beginning.
So it's the path that most people take to becoming writers or long-going work.
And that doesn't apply only to the science fiction field, but to any literature.
